This plot totally makes no sense. It seems rather dry because all that the character do is...CATER TO THIS MAIN CHARACTER. I'm sure they catered this to the average man who would want girls on their hand and foot like that. The whole Anime feels rather fake. Maybe they should make these girls more 'realistic' ya know?


Rin only ends up with one person in the end of course. But who? Well I am going to have to make you watch the crappy drama and what not to find out. Too bad, I can't spoil the Anime for you.


Overall, this Anime is like some kind of funky Japanese Soap Opera. It has its ups-and-downs. Watch at your own risk. I was about to drop it myself, but I was just curious as to who the jerk would end up with!


However, if you do not want to watch it because I would never, ever want to watch it again...look it up online.


I recommend this Anime for guys more than girls in the end. It is more of a guy anime than a girl anime. 



Happy Anime Hunting!~ The above review is my opinion and it may not be the same as yours. I respect other people's opinions because one person's vision of an Anime can be totally different from another vision. People perceive things in different ways.

Shuffle! is a generic romance harem story, featuring most of what is generally accepted to be good and unfortunately bad about its type of show. For those who have never seen a show of this genre, it's probably a good place to start to accumulate a background on the common traits of these types of shows.  Besides that it's a pretty unexceptional show, and a rather poor adaptation of its related visual novel (having experienced both, I will immediately tell you the visual novel is by far superior).
Starting with whats good, this show is not particularly animated most of the time being more onthe lines of slice of life (although there are a few notable exceptions). That being said it's mostly an aesthetically pleasing show with well drawn characters, and of course, it can't really hurt to have a lot of beautiful girls in the main cast can it? A few dramatic moments here and there did get some good visual emphasis as well. The voice actors (both English and Japanese) are pretty well chosen for the most part, and fans of the visual novel can at least appreciate the reuse of the same Japanese actors. Being based on an eroge, this show does present some obvious nudity, but for the most part it's not overdone, and it's usually humorous, so it generally shouldn't detract from your viewing experience much, if it even does.


The visual novel doesn't necessarily have the best plot ever, and unfortunately one of the problems with this show is trying too hard to fit too much all at once. Besides the fact that obviously Rin is only supposed to end up with one of the girls, the way Shuffle! attempts to translate all the routes into some kind of relevant single story ends up leaving our main protagonist Rin a very weak and indecisive man. This above all else is the single biggest flaw of Shuffle! the anime, a horrible main protagonist who is never willing to commit to anything, leaving many many people hanging and feeling desperate. This alone makes most of the characters (namely the girls and Rin) have seemingly shallow motivations, and is a primary reason why the visual novel is superior, since there is no indecision on Rin's part when you as the player make all the important choices.


For the most part the show generally tries to cut and paste stuff that happened from the visual novel into the show. To be fair though, a few things like Kaede's background and maybe to a lesser extent Sia's as well do get directed in a more interesting way than the visual novel presents. So for the sake of saying whether or not the anime does anything to separate itself from the visual novel, there is something to consider.


All in all Shuffle! is a fairly average show. It's mostly okay, a few good moments here and there, and unfortunately the show is held back by a lame protagonist, who as a result makes much of the plot a lot more lame than it should be.  If you're still curious about learning what the romantic harem genre has to offer, this show is definitely one to consider looking into.

NOTES:
First review ever, so don't be too angry if it's not as good as you'd like.  :)
This is a review for people who are looking to watch the show/interested in overarching details.
------------
I'm going to try and be as absolutely forgiving to this anime as I possibly can be, because for the better part of the series, I enjoyed the living hell out of it.
However, after investing my psyche in a story about a supposed harem contest between what you could call a flock of girls (three of which happened to be supernaturally-inclined), I got a serving of the most unnecessarily dramatic and overly playedformula that the writers could have come up with, and for that, I have to call this anime what it is: contrived dreck.


On with the review!


The ART was amazing - really over par for the time in which it was drawn.  Sometimes when the characters' faces would be at different angles, I was a bit upset with the hasty way that the animators would kinda just slap some facial features on there and really not care about where they ended up, but hey, it's a cartoon first and foremost so I can't really be too judgmental about that.  The backdrops, the animation and the visual stills were really well done, so I gave it an 8 overall.


The SOUND was also well done.  Seiyuus portrayed their characters just how I would have thought they would have sounded, and the emotion was definitely where it needed to be.  I never watched the OP/ED, but from what I did get just by not being able to be completely accurate with my video position bar, it sounded like every other cheesy harem anthem, so I can't really call it out for that (maybe for lack of originality - I digress).  The music was largely forgettable and didn't really sound as though it was a large part of the budget, but it added to the mood when necessary and wasn't overtly unwelcome - gave this category a 7.


Here's where I get nasty.


The CHARACTERS were stereotypical, unimaginative, overly dramatic and largely disappointing.  To avoid spoilers (and the rage that would spill into my writing from thinking about their personas in-depth again), I'm going to simply give an  overarching synopsis of why I felt the characters could have been about 178,000 times better than they were.


In most situations, the characters played their assigned role - by about episode 7, every character you were introduced to had their persona already laid out flat, and you or I could have written the dialogue for them from there.  This is not what upset me the most, as it is what those of us who watch the harem/rom-com/drama genre have come to expect in terms of character depth (which in and of itself is kind of a travesty - I digress).


What really pissed me off about the writers' lack of imagination is that they tried to cover it up by throwing curveballs at both the characters and the viewer that were ABSOLUTELY contrived and COMPLETELY irrelevant whilst still trying to remain in a genre that they had forsaken long before then.  A note to the writers on this: when you write a character the same for 2/3rd's of a series and then decide LET'S CHANGE THEIR PERSONALITY BECAUSE WE CAN or some other bullshit, this does not "make things fresh" or "add intrigue" - you'll get some "what the fuck" factor and it infuriates most involved viewers.


Some would argue that the twists thrown in add to the atmosphere and that the drama was necessary - to these people, I say "Did you watch the first half to two-thirds of the show?"  It is both DISMANTLING to a plot line and VERY UNSETTLING to see a show go from overly cute and bubbly to downright nasty in the span of an episode.  There's no build up, and over the course of the past twelve to thirteen episodes, you've given me nothing but panty shot after panty shot mixed in with an un/fortunate situation thrown in every now and again - now you slap me in the face with an overly serious situation that rivals Jersey Shore levels of what these writers would call dramatic plot movement WITHOUT maintaining the cuteness you'd been stringing me along with for the past FOREVER?  M. Night Shayamayamyamaymayamalan could write better twists, AND at least he'd have the decency not to lie to me for 15 episodes about it.  It's like the show tried to emulate what another show (Higurashi no Naku Koro ni, a FANTASTIC dark comedy) did, but they forgot to tell their viewers.


Another thing is screen time: at one point in the series, the two most important girls to the story up to that point (those who are vying to marry our male lead) completely disappear without a word from the other characters as to what's going on with them, even though ; this would have been acceptable and even welcome had it been for an episode - maybe two, but it literally happens for about three to four episodes, and when they finally DO come back into the story, they've been relegated to overtly stereotypical dialogue and AT BEST an auxiliary character role.  I gave the CHARACTERS category a 4 because before the writers decided to screw up the roles and give every character some atrocious character flaw, I actually enjoyed the stereotypical interactions.


Finally, the STORY.  This is probably where I find the most wrong with the anime, and also where I have the least to say - simply because, the one and only thing I found atrocious about this story is that there really wasn't one, and they were trying so hard in the beginning to present a coherent comedic romance.


With a few, very MINOR exceptions, there is no such thing as 'missing an episode' with this series; because of the way that the writers decided to introduce character flaws and try to add what they thought were appropriate levels of drama, they completely destroyed what semblance of a plot line they had and any interaction at all before those points becomes absolutely meaningless - not to mention the LITANY of re-uses of written lines and plot devices to try and maintain said levels of what they thought was "drama".  I gave the STORY category a 5 as well, simply because for the majority of the beginning of the series, I was enjoying what could be called the plot.


OVERALL, I found this series to start fantastically strong but finish with a bitter taste in my mouth, an underhanded and unwelcome attempt to become a different genre, and characters that (as time went on) became more and more unbearable to watch.  Had Shuffle! stuck with the rom-com/harem-style from start to finish, this could have been another fantastic addition to the genre (and not to mention some super pantsu shots) - instead, the writers tried to add depth where it wasn't necessary, drama where it wasn't wanted, and twists that not only made the characters dull and used, but also overly self-righteous and sometimes downright stupid.


Hope you find this review helpful!

Story:
This is where Shuffle! excels the most. There are at least 4 or 5 arcs packed into 24 episodes, so by the time you finish, you can’t say you didn’t get your money’s worth. I was hesitant about watching at first, but this anime can’t be judged by the impression the first two episodes give, because there’s a whole lot more to it. Every episode you learn a little more about a certain character, which makes a good incentive to continue. Most of the plot is filled with twists, but some episodes (especially the last few) are predictable. 
Art:
This anime looks much older than itreally is. I don’t know if it’s because of the shading or choice of colors, but the characters look really flat, which takes some getting used to. If I had to make a comparison, I’d say this anime looks like Higurashi no Naku Koro ni. What I do like is that the animation is very fluid. It’s like watching an oil painting in motion. The backgrounds and lighting effects are especially nice. 


Sound:

The OP and ED themes immediately became one of my favorites the first time I heard it. It was hard to stop listening and sometimes I found myself humming them. The BGM on the other hand is a whole different story. Most of the tunes sound like something out of a 90’s video game. Again, it makes the anime feel more dated than it really is. Although I guess you could call it nostalgic if you want to, since the characters are in their teens. It’s unique, but definitely not for everyone. Even worse, it gets repetitive pretty quickly, but at least the right tunes are always played at the right time according to what’s happening on screen.


Character:

Rarely have I seen characters with this much personality. Both the male and female characters are nicely developed (no pun intended). The girls are beautiful on the outside, yet they each have their own set of flaws. I’m sure everyone who watches Shuffle! will find a favorite character -- mine’s Kaede, followed by Primula. XD But I wish some characters would have had more screen time. It seemed two or three girls took over the show while the rest of the cast was placed behind, which is really unfortunate.


Enjoyment:

I recommend everyone to watch Shuffle! because there’s something for everybody -- comedy, romance, happiness, sadness, and even good fan service. Shuffle! is downright funny, but will have you on the edge of your seat just as often.


Overall:

There are many harem animes out there, but Shuffle! is one of the few that does it right. As I mentioned above, despite its looks, this isn’t your run-of-the-mill anime. If you’re looking for a good romance, a light-hearted comedy, or just something with a bunch of twists, Shuffle! is one anime that you won’t forget about anytime soon.

Let me just explain that when I picked up this anime, I had just finished watching AnoHana, and was hoping for a light-hearted romance/comedy/harem to let my brain settle before delving into another intense anime. But Shuffle! was NOT as easy-going as I was expecting. So although this anime was good, it was not what I was expecting, and therefore I may be a tad bias in my review. 
Story: 7
As far as the story goes, I liked the idea of Gods, Demons and Humans all living together. I'm a fan of the comedy/romance/drama/harem genre. And I like how they tie magic into the wholeseries. So why am I only giving the story a 7? 


Let me try to explain my thinking with a simple episode breakdown:


Episodes 1-12ish: Character building episodes. Really basic. A simple problem each episode that is resolved by the end of the episode, and reveals bits and pieces of each characters personality. Although these episodes are essential for the rest of the anime, they do tend to drag on a little. So I wasn't a big fan of that. NOTE: The atmosphere in these episodes are light and romantic, standard for the genre.


Episodes 13ish-16ish: An arch is given that takes all attention off of the main plot(Rin's love life) and focuses on one character(Primula, who is not fighting for Rin's affection). Although the arch wasn't bad, it was a complete and sudden change of atmosphere, from light and romantic to dramatic and magical. This again isn't a bad thing, it's just not what I was expecting from the show. ANOTHER NOTE: Throughout this point, the anime did a really good job of keeping me guessing as far as who Rin would choose, which is surprising. In this kind of anime, it is usually painfully obvious which girl the main character is going to end up with. But in Shuffle!, i thought I had it narrowed down to one of two girls, but I was completely wrong. Which is a big plus for this anime.


Episodes 17ish-24ish: ALL. HELL. BREAKS. LOOSE. An obsessive girl with the inability to move on + a guy who is ready to move on + a whole lot of tears + one character being hospitalized + a late game suicide attempt + somehow a happy ending = My brain falling apart and me repeatedly asking "what the hell is going on here?" The anime plunges into emotions, drama, and painful flashbacks at a pace that left my head spinning. Again, I love emotion-filled romance/drama animes(like AnoHana), but I had JUST finished AnoHana before watching Shuffle!, so these episodes were NOT what I was expecting/hoping for from this anime. 


Overall, the story didn't have any major holes in it, and it all wrapped up nicely without leaving me feeling overly rushed. Had I been expecting the ending to be so... dark... then I would have gladly given the story a 9, but whereas I was hoping for a lighter watch, I only gave it a 7. 


Art: 8


As far as I know, the anime had pretty good art for an anime created in 2006. The series did go a tad overboard with fan service, but I'm a 17 year old guy, so I'm not complaining.


Sound: 8


Again, as far as I know, the sound effects were pretty good for an anime created in 2006. The opening song was rather catchy, and the end song was nothing spectacular, so an 8 here seems fair.


Characters: 8


This show had a terrific cast of characters. Each girl had their own unique background story, so even though each fell into one cliché or another, they still felt fresh. Primula was one of those characters that won't be forgotten easily, just because of how adorable she is. 


I did have one big problem with this anime though; Rin, the male lead. It was downright annoying how 99% of the people around him would do ANYTHING to get closer to him. It was just obnoxious. It's impossible to put into words how much I detest Rin. BUT, aside from my strong hatred of Rin, all of the other characters bring something cute/unique/hilarious to the table, so I give it an 8.


Enjoyment: 7 


Again, my enjoyment is heavily affected by how different the show was from what I expected. But I still enjoyed the show quite a bit, so a 7 seems fair enough.


Overall: 8


This show has a little something for everyone; whether it be the romance, comedy, drama, school life, magic, or fan service, you name it, this anime has it. I definitely recommend this anime to anyone who is willing to deal with an annoying male lead in exchange for a pretty darn good romance/comedy/harem/drama/school life anime.


P.S. This is my first review, so if you have ANY feedback(good or bad) just send me an email/message/whatever, and I will try to make my next review better. :)

10 years ago, the realm between the Gods, Demons & the human world was irreversibly opened, giving an excuse to add the supernatural/magic to Shuffle!; the humans, demons & Gods inevitably come together as a lot of the demons & Gods migrate freely into the human world, changing the Shuffle! world forever.
You may be off-set by hearing the general overview of the series, but demons/gods & magic don't play as big a role as one might think by simply seeing a review. In fact, there are only 2 serious/emotionally-driven scenes where they use magic in this series and neither are against any adversary/foe and bothare in the more-to-the point second season. 


Shuffle is probably one of the better harem anime. The first season has a lot of comic relief whereas the second is much more serious comparatively, though both have their pros and cons. The first season is more about character connections than it is the main plot which, you'll find, is very necessary when watching Shuffle!


As stated, the second season is much more emotional and in depth story-wise than the first with one of the more emotional arcs (12-15) coming at the beginning of the second season. Basically, the first season is much more involved with character development and the second with story.



The animation quality was excellent. On the more unique side of things, the character design/clothing for each main character changes a lot throughout the series and you can't grasp any character in one outfit for long, further adding to the variety of the overall series. For those who prefer to watch the dub, don't hesitate as Shuffle! is one of the better English dubbed anime and each of the characters voices fit nicely.


I enjoyed the series a lot more than I thought I would by initially seeing reviews of it and I expect anyone who watches it with an open mind to do the same, though I can see if it really isn't your style. In short, my Shuffle! experience was great and I wouldn't change that much. The fan-service doesn't interfere with the main plot, though there are a few ecchi situations. 


Overall rating of the series: 9/10. Exceeded expectations.

Shuffle! is a harem anime that suffers from ADD, depression and drunken incoherence. The original opening concept is actually pretty interesting. This universe has your standard Earth and humans but also openly welcomes Gods and Demons which are basically elven looking humanoids. The King of the world of the gods and the King of the world of the demons each have a daughter and the one who marries them will become the ruler of the gods or ruler of the demons. Naturally, these girls are in love with a Japanese loser from highschool. Yeah, that makes for a pretty interesting concept right? not super originalbut damn entertaining... throw in some additional girls and you have a recipe for an amazing anime, right? Wrong. While the premise is good, its execution fails so spectacularly that it is almost hard to believe. 


The whole entire premise that would make it interesting is almost instantly dropped. It becomes a simple "confused feelings" anime and this main character manages to literally ruin several lives in the process. I have never EVER seen a main character who I hated more due to his thoughtless and selfish nature that they wanted to come across as innocent. It was hard to stomach. I wont say who he ends up with but needless to say that the whole "Becoming king of the gods or king of the demons" is almost never mentioned again and the kings are rarely seen past the opening episodes. What a damn waste.


If this anime wanted to be what it ended up being, then fine... but why introduce the element king of the god or demon world at all? I have no problem with the main character ending up with whoever but it could have been done much better.


This anime tries very hard to be as ridiculous as possible with the character personalities. You have characters who start to go insane, literally, out of the blue... and degenerate into a completely different character, doing things uncharacteristic of their pre-established personalities and then by the end going back as if nothing had happened. 


There is also a lot of pointless drama. I don't mind drama, hell I like it if its done right... but here it is not... at least not towards the second half. I guess that is what it comes down to thought. The series gets progressively worse, to the point where it seems like one director was fired halfway though and another took their place and wanted to re-write the entire story.


You can find better.


And if you liked Shuffle! fantastic. I didn't. My review is based on that basis.


STORY: Great concept. Unforgivable execution.


ART: The animation was pretty good. Nothing to write home about but overall it was fluid and nice. I don't have any complaints but it didn't blow me away or anything. The thing that stood out were the eyes... in a good way.


SOUND::The opening theme is awesome. I liked it a lot. The rest though isnt memorable. you will forget it in T-minus 30 seconds.


CHARACTER: Uhgg... no. Just no. I have never seen characters that are more all over the place in terms of personality. 


ENJOYMENT: Very little but what little I did enjoy, I enjoyed quite a bit.


OVERALL: I personally found little enjoyment out of this title, but the stuff I did enjoy was pretty good. I couldnt get passed the fact that they managed to be so all over the place with the story. Virtus Signum gives this a 4/10. Below Average.

Shuffle wasn't an anime I was ever keen on watching to be honest. Partly because of Nerine's ears and partly because it just didn't appeal to me. I ended up watching it because a friend gave it raving reviews and I just couldn't believe I'd ever been stupid enough to pass it over.
Before I get on with the review, I'm going to have to give out two warnings:
1) This anime will repeatedly threaten to compromise your manliness, if you're a guy. 
2) This anime also contains one of my favorite characters and she was the one who awakened my inner lolicon. She could do thesame to you.


Now for the review.


Story - 9

Unusually for a harem this anime had an abundance of story. Whilst it lacked a plot that stretched throughout the whole 24 episodes, each heroine had a few episodes that was dedicated to her with minimum interference from the other female leads. This makes a nice change from the usual constant squabble-fest of other harems which, whilst entertaining enough, do get a little old. Even the filler episodes served to let the background characters take center stage for a little and to see how they are going about their business. The ending is also one of the most satisfying in the harem genre. Shuffle covers just about every genre going, so don't be put off by the word 'harem' because it is so much more than that.


Art - 9

I'm giving the art a 9, even though it is the area of Shuffle I have the most beef with. Particularly with the character art. Some characters are visually superb, such as Reena and Sia. Then you have a character like Asa who walks around with hair that looks like a huge chunk of green and Kaede who has hair so glaringly orange it would make oranges cry. These are minor faults  and are just the result of me having high standards so I'm not going to be petty and lower the score for it.


Sound - 9 

The opening theme, You (song name, not you you), is one of my favorite theme songs in anime to date. The music seems to fit the events and emotions of the anime no matter what is happening, which, considering how diverse Shuffle is, is pretty impressive. I won't give it a perfect score because nothing about the rest of the sound is really memorable to me.


Characters - 10

Just to be clear, I do not like all of Shuffle's characters. The daydreamer Kareha being the main culprit and the main Rin, not far behind. This isn't because they are bad characters though. I don't like them purely because of one or two minor things they do/did that irked me.

The rest of the characters are just..... amazing. They all have a past that, thanks to the dedication of episodes specifically for them, are explained in enough detail so we feel we know the character without their pasts becoming the dominating theme. I think the creators did very well juggling character development from the past and character development in the present. They are hardly 'generic' either. You do have the normal generic types of girls found in harems but each come with their own twist in Shuffle that really brings a breath of fresh air to the genre.

And Rimu. I have to give Rimu her own paragraph. I defy you to watch this and  then to not like Rimu. She fills the 'emotionless loli' role but still somehow manages to convey emotion. Her background story is heart wrenching to watch. I was genuinely concerned about her, a fictional character. She is just such a lovable character. Cherami Leigh's performance as Rimu is nothing short of spectacular.


Enjoyment - 9 

I enjoyed Shuffle immensely. It's a new type of harem anime, it's diverse and interesting, the fanservice is kept to an absolute minimum (maybe once or twice in 24 episodes.) You cannot help loving at least one character. It's a horrible analogy but it was similar to betting on the horse races. I had my favorite girl and wanted her to be chosen over the other by Rin (or win the race, in other words.) It was definitely enjoyable rooting for my favorite.


Overall - 9 

All the reasons why this is just a great anime to watch are ^^^^^ up there.

I might've given it a perfect 10 but for one or two itty bitty issues here and there which some people would ignore but I can't. This is purely personal preference though. Also the fact I have so much to say about an anime I last watched in March gives testament to how... memorable this is. 

Definitely one to watch.

Tsuchimi Rin is a high school student who attends National Verbena Academy. He spends his time with childhood friend Fuyo Kaeda and Shigure Asa. One day, two beautiful girls from the world of gods and devils transfer to his class and another artificial life form moves in with him. All 5 girls love Rin. Now he has to decide who will be the one he spends the rest of his life with.
Story & Characters (8/10)
The story of Shuffle! is yet another twist on the romance/comedy genre. While staying traditional to the harem style scenario, Shuffle! adds magical elements and outstanding character development into the mix.The favoritism of the childhood friend scenario seems to play prominent in the series and all of the characters have their good points. This is great when trying to create characters that you can get attached to, however it does make it rather difficult to choose a favorite as you don't want to see any of them get hurt. Also, because the characters all seem to have some sort of promise, it makes the balance seem slightly off. Still, it's a minor complaint. Fans of such series as Ichigo 100% and Sister Princess will find it easy to grasp Shuffle! as it stays with the traditional multi-girl style without becoming too ecchi in the process.


Art (9/10)

The artwork was originally conceived from a dating sim game of the same title. Thus all of the character designs are very crisp and the execution is quite capivating. The backgrounds are lush and continue to flow steadily with every scene but you find almost all of your attention on the characters themselves. The males are portrayed accordingly the the females are all beautiful in their own way. As far as the traditional harem genre is concerned, I have found Shuffle! to maintain some of the best artwork.


Sound (9/10)

The music in Shuffle! is outstanding to say the least. The intro song "You" but YURIA is a fastpaced song that is well coordinated with the intro animation. The lyrics also give off a sense of desperation from the singer which promotes well with the female leads in the anime. The ending theme "Innocence" is slower and more peaceful than the intro, but the lyrics continue to grasp the series well and will leave you wanting more. The song tone and lyrics are well delivered as well. Follow the series into the OSTs, and you'll find quite a bit of music to keep your ears happy. "In The Sky" is another prominent song that emerged from the game and you will find it to be an excellent piece if your a fan of the traditional music in the anime. The normal background music isn't anything to snear at either. Without being too prominent, the background music is soft and blends well with the animation scenarios at hand. The variations are kept to a minor note but are still distinctive enough to embrace the situation.


Overall (9/10)

I feel that the overall aspect of Shuffle! was quite enjoyable. The humor of the series is rather clean for the most part and the overall story flows nicely from episode to episode. Unlike a lot of series in the same genre, Shuffle! has captured me with its lack of filler episodes. Every episode seems to play nicely into one another even if only to show the tightening bonds betweem the male protagonist and one of the female leads. There are also a few story arcs that are thrown into the mix to keep the flow straight forward and on task. There is a small span in which Nerine is the primary focus of the male lead, then there is another with Sia as the focal of attention, then you will find a lot of tension with the Primula arc that has yet to be completed. Throughout the series, they manage to keep your interest captivated with a different scenario. The execution of the art is by far superior to that of other titles in the same category and the music only serves to smoothen the delivery of it all. Taking everything into account, Shuffle!'s crisp artwork and excellent soundtrack with leave romance/comedy fans planted in their seats and asking for more. So, I would totally recommend this anime who like these kind of genre or to people just starting out.

This is an anime that will cause you try and drown yourself in a pool of bleach. It is completely awful to watch, more painful than driving rusty nails through your eyes. School Days is a better anime than this in that at least some of the demented characters get killed. This anime, sadly, doesn't have this wonderful ending.
Story: An indecisive dumbass attracts a bunch of dumbass females. The plot here is literally the indecisiveness. That's not a story, that's shit.
Sound: Unfortunately there is sound, I wish it was silent with no subtitles or anything.
Character: Amazing character development as to how fucking stupid they canbe.\n\n
Enjoyment: Alcohol tested, it fails.

Shuffle! is a truly great harem in the world of anime. It certainly had the potential to be a masterpiece if it wasn't for the overly unrealistic setting. Then again of course, it's not something these type of animes worry about. Most harems have an unrealistic setting that would not be possible in the real world. Therefore, you're either going to like or hate this anime straight away. 
The story might seem cliched ie. one guy x lots of girls = suspence and drama (+ the occasional fanservice). That's not the case in Shuffle! however. This anime manages to suprise us all the time withthings we wouldn't expect to see in it after watching a few episodes. Having watched quite a few harems myself, I expected the same old routine... guy wakes up, guy goes to school, guy meets dozens of girls. Girls fall in love with the guy, guy doesn't know what to do but somehow he "accidentaly" ends up groping all of them. 


I was pleasantly suprised that Shuffle! decided to reverse the roles and in fact it's the male lead getting groped... and not accidentaly. Very similar to how it was done in nagasarete airantou, albeit with less nudity. 


What most Harem animes lack is comic relief. Every anime needs it. Even death note had a few scenes which were designed to make the viewer laugh. Shuffle! doesn't disappoint. A lot of characters in this anime were made just for that. Like the "defense forces" for example. As it turns out there ARE actually jealous men in this anime which is definitively a first. I've never seen a jealous guy in any other harem anime that I've watched. It's usually something like "ohh yeah that dude... meh who cares." Out here it's more like "GAH! he's got all the girls, let's get him!" which also suprised me. 


So what are the defense forces? Organised groups of adult (and not so adult) men who try to capture the male lead with the intention of executing him in various ways. Of course, they always fail miserably. 


The characters are awesome. We have Rin Tsuchimi, the prontagonist of the series. He's an average highschool dude, with one exception. He's a powerful chick magnet. What's more (and this is where total unrealism I mentioned earlier sets in), most of the girls that are interested in him are either demons or gods. Rin shrugs off the girls' advances most of the time which just makes them more daring and determined. Add to that the fact that most of the fathers and mothers in this anime want their daughters to get intimate with the male lead (wtf) and... wham, you have the perfect recipe for "what the hell did I just watch" moments.


Sound is really nothing special, just your average anime music. There is seriously nothing I could write about on that. Well no, there is one thing - the opening is very long, it probably constitutes 15% of every single episode. Likewise art is good but it's not super awesome... or even awesome for that matter. It simply is good. No mistakes or anything but it's not breathtaking. 


Enjoyment is probably what this anime is about. It's not one of those "teach you a lesson" or "tear-jerker" animes, it's simple here to entertain you. That said though, you're gonna have to get used to the unrealistic setting and simply focus on the story instead. A bit like in "ah my goddess". Anyway, I encourage you to take a look, Shuffle! is a fine addition to the Harem genre. 


Great anime, great score.

Shuffle! is one of those little diamonds in the anime world. From the start you think its your average harem with a dumb guy and girls all yearning for him with a bunch of comedy and randomness thrown in. But Shuffle! did something that a lot a harems don't... its keeps a lot of secrets.
Throughout the show new secrets, twists and pure surprises are revealed. one of the main being which girl he would pick, from the start you have no idea who it will be which I think is brill.
It also has some very dark parts to it, especially in the second half ofthe show that really do take you by surprise.\n\n
Overall this is a great series for anyone, not just us harem lovers, it bring such a different feel to a harem and I do believe its one of the more unique harems out there and possibly one of the best too. My overall rating is a solid 9.

Warning possible Spoilers
I like to think of Shuffle as one of the few gems of the Ecchi/Harem area because instead of relying on fan service with a lot of action it focuses more on character which is what drew me to it in the first place.
The story is set in a world where God's, Demon's and Humans co-exist, the MC Rin Tsuchimi and his friend Kaede Fuyou find that the king of both God's and Demon's have become their neighbours who also have daughters who are in love with Rin so Rin must make a choice on who to pick.
Even though the story does whatmost harems do it also decides to concentrate on the female characters too as each girl in the show that are a part of the harem have a dark backstory and that is what made the story good in my opinion because it doesn't rely much on fan service and out of 24 episodes I probably only saw nudity like 4 to 7 times which is pretty low for and Ecchi/Harem this long and when it does do it, it seems like a realistic situation for it to happen, it's also intresting finding out about the God's and demon's worlds, what differences they have and whether they have different abilities too, but the most interesting aspect is that the story focuses on a different girl at some point in the show some get more screentime than others which kind of annoyed me, but this is one of those few Ecchi/Harems where the MC actually picks someone in the end making the journey more worthwhile.


The characters were certainly an interesting bunch Rin compared to other Harem MC's isn't too bad and when he does something dense he actually acknowledges it and despite avoiding the big question all the time he does generally care for each of the female characters making him a more likeable character too.

The female characters are definitely the most interesting part of the show considering almost every one of them has a dark backstory of sorts like for example Sia has a split personality complex, Nerine has a similar sort of complex, but is much different compared to Sia's, Kaede is a yandere just gonna say that, Primula is a God + Demon experiment and Asa has a dark secret that shows she isn't fully human. Seeing each of these characters stories become more complete was a very thrilling and emotional journey because some fared worse than others and it makes you feel sorry for them.

The other supporting characters that aren't a part of the harem were also enjoyable too like the God and demon kings who seemed like really friendly guys, but can also be serious when the time comes for it, the other two characters like Mayumi who is a Tsundere mainly because people pick on her breast size which is always funny and Itsuki who is a perverted womaniser, but does have a gentle heart and these characters were actually entertaining whenever they were on screen.


Now the artstyle was interesting it reminded me of When They Cry you know Female characters with small heads and large amounts of hair which made them stand out a lot.


Now the Romance in this show was actually pretty good considering I didn't know which to stick up for mainly because they were nice girls the dark part of their lives was also something to take into account, but I was generally surprised that Rin actually picked someone which happens rarely in the Ecchi/Harem so it was a nice change for it to go into this direction and of course there is fan-service, but this time it feels more mature compared to other Ecchi/Harems and whenever it did show nudity it felt like a realistic situation that would actually happen.


Overall I think this was an enjoyable and entertaining show and if you're someone who enjoys watching Ecchi/Harem anime's then I'd consider this since it is more mature compared to the majority and it also focuses more on it's characters too.

This is very belated, what with it being 2017 as I write this, but, if you actually get down to my review, I hope you'll find it helpful.
   This is an important anime.  The reason is because of the very serious issues it addresses, that the writers buried in the harem aspects.
    It is the only anime I've ever seen that addresses ALL of the following issues:
   Post Traumatic Stress Disorder
   Abortion and the possible consequences thereof.
    Just how far is it ethical to go when experimentingon humans?


    What should the rights of clones be?


    How should we react to family groupings that are outside the norm?


    What do you do when you find out that someone you've blamed for years for a horrific situation was actually protecting you and it was your fault?


    Not discussing a situation with someone who could help you can result in a potentially fatal result.


    How do you deal with guilt over a situation that you didn't participate in but which was of great benefit to you?


   The writers also handled the use of symbolism, in the literary sense, in an excellent manner.  They used it to emphasize the other questions they presented.  It was done so well/smoothly that I suspect that most people missed it.

Shuffle! was something that I went into with very few expectations. I generally don't watch older anime for a myriad of different reasons, but shuffle! did interest me for some reason. The plot seemed kinda out there for what you generally get in a romcom and it was that reason alone that made me decide to start watching it. I will say this much about it, if you are tired of the same formula in romcoms and want something a bit different then shuffle! might be the anime for you. Not only is the world it takes place in different, but how they go aboutwith character development and even who the MC actually ends up with are quite un-expected and interesting because of that. It's an anime that has genuine plot twists. Some stuff you can see coming, but some of the bigger events that take place genuinely catch you by surprise and that's always something I welcome with open arms when it comes to the anime industry. 


Story- A basic rundown of the synopsis is this " God, demons, and regular humans now co-exist together. The kings of both the demon and god realm move into houses next to the MC and want him to marry either of their daughters." That is the setup for the plot and imo it does follow some of the basic tropes of "girls move into the mc's house or next to him" but what makes it interesting is his connection to either of those girls. Not only that but they're the daughters of the king of demons and gods respectively and with that comes some unique circumstances. Those aren't the only girls he has a connection to, but they're the ones that are presented to us at the start. Where things progress from here are rather...well fundamental I would say. It does for a while follow a basic path that most romcoms take, which is fine, afterall you can't exactly get a connection the characters and care about them without anything happening, but what I loved about the story is the fact that it doesn't stay on this path for long. It lets you get to know and care for the characters, it gives them enough time to get to know the MC and most importantly it gives all the characters enough motivation to pursue the MC for different reasons rather than just "Daddy said I had to". Where the anime gets really interesting though is after it strays from this path. Certain events take place that leads to a sort of second arc where the dynamic of the show changes and that is where the good and memorable parts of the show happen.


Art- I'm not gonna lie here, the art and animation in general is fairly generic despite the type of universe the anime takes place in. I feel like they could have done more to emphasize the kind of world they were in. One gripe I do have is that they don't show nearly as much of the demon and god worlds as they should have despite them seeming very interesting from how they're described.  It's not bad by any means, but this is one of the animes that would have benefited a lot more from having better art design. It's serviceable.


Sound- The sounds assets and design are good, but nothing really original in my mind. It does what it's suppose to and the music sets the mood, some of the tracks are actually quite good to be honest, but there weren't any tracks I would say were mindblowing. The intro was the best piece of music in the whole anime imo. 


Character- To me the characters and rather un-predictable plots twists are what make shuffle! a memorable show and experience. The characters in shuffle! have true character development, not all of them, but some of them truly change for the better or worse throughout the series. To me what really made the show interesting was who the MC actually ended up with, not only that but how much the character he chose developed. A character I didn't care too much for all of a sudden became someone that I cared for deeply. The only bad thing about romcoms with multiple girls are that the enjoyment of the show can hinge on who the MC ends up with. I can see why some people wouldn't like the girl he chose and that could ruin the show for them, but the bottom line is that Shuffle! has a great cast of characters all of which are well fleshed out and portrayed. Each girl does get a fair chance with the MC, there are even times when you think that he is gonna end up with some of them, but ultimately I think he makes the right choice. 


Enjoyment- The enjoyment of romcoms hinge on you liking the plot and characters. If either of those fall flat that usually makes for a bad experience, who the MC ends up with can also determine if you enjoyed the show or not. The setting of Shuffle! while quite unique, could be seen as something that would be a turn off for some people. The characters on the other hand I think are objectively well made and well portrayed, not everyone is going to like a tsundere character for example, but that doesn't mean a tsundere character isn't well made and well portrayed. I enjoyed the setting, plot, and characters ton in shuffle!. Combined with some genuinely surprising plot twists and developments along with pretty good pacing and amazing writing makes for a great experience in my opinion. It's entirely understandable why some people wouldn't like shuffle!, but it's worth giving a shot if the premise of it sounds intriguing to you, it's also worth giving a shot if you want something a bit different from the standard romcom animes. 


Overall- Overall shuffle! was a great experience for me and I really enjoyed my time with it despite me going into it not expecting too much. I would reccomend this to people that want something a bit different from the romcom genre.

For all the people that disliked this anime and are about to question my line of thought for it's rating, or are about to "unhelpful" this review, hear me out.
Shuffle! is a great anime that shows supernatural, comedic, dramatic, and romantic scenes in beautifully constructed ways. The show is structured very simply at the beginning, where it's just Rin's normal way of living with Kaede, who takes care of him and goes to school with him. Later on in school they meet up with Asa Shigure, as they probably usually do. But there is a surprise in their class when it is said there aretwo new students transferring. These happen to be princesses of the Gods and Demons, and also happen to know Rin from their childhood. They both fight for his hand in marriage, and they're fathers try really hard as well to help out their daughters. The reason i'm stating everything like this is because many people believe that everything was introduced so quickly. But that's where they're wrong. The anime started where all the events started to occur, and the transitions seemed smooth, because it felt like everything, up until the two princesses came along, seemed to happen everyday. So I feel like it had started at the right time.


Something about school oriented animes seem to enrage people. If one of the genres say "School" and your not a big fan of it, then why watch it? I feel like Shuffle! would be stupid without this setting. Kaede wouldn't have met Asa, so Rin wouldn't have met her either. This would destroy the series, so there's no reason to dislike it. I feel like itis a huge help to the anime, and most of the scenarios do not even occur in school.


Sorry for my ranting, here's the Genre Rating:

Comedy, Drama, Ecchi, Fantasy, Magic, Romance, School, Harem, Seinen


Drama - 30 out of 30

The series doesn't start off too dramatic, usually only through jealousy from the girls. But what really hits hard is Kaede's and Asa's arc. The amount of anxiety and depression between these two arcs are insanely emotional. I won't go into detail due to spoilers, but these scenes caused me to keep constantly thinking back on them well after I finished the series. Primula also has a pretty emotional arc, and that's why Drama get's all of it's points.


Harem - 25 out of 25

Yes, I consider the Harem genre as second to drama. But the whole Harem idea is crucial in Shuffle! Not only do they all try to get Rin to love them without regard to his feelings, he also tries very hard to spend time and be kind to them all equally. Only later does Rin realize his stupidity and how he's only hurting each of them more the longer he waits to choose. So I give Shuffle! a lot of credit for the skillful use of Harem.


Romance - 20 out of 20

To be very honest, there's isn't much romance to go on about in the beginning, with some exceptions here and there. But then, when you figure out who Rin really loves, romance booms, to the point where it is surprising. And then there are many circumstances that come with this love, causing in many heart-warming scenes and very saddening scenes all the same, which causes the romatic parts to be somewhat enhanced.


School - 13 out of 15

I did just make a big deal about how school was very important to Shuffle!, yet there is one thing that kept it from getting a perfect score. Lisanthius and Nerine both switch into Rin's class. Right then, it seems like all the main characters are all in the same class and are also sitting next to each other, which bothered me a great deal. But as I said before, the series wouldn't be much without the school setting, so it was very significant in Shuffle!


Ecchi - 10 out of 10

Can you believe this? An anime that uses ecchi to increase problems for the main male protagonist and is used in these situations smartly? I couldn't believe that Shuffle! could actually use ecchi other than fan service, even though some scenes were obviously fan service. Besides those, the use of ecchi was all in all creating problems for Rin throughout, most notebly Kaede and Sia. Some people may complain that it is unneccessary, but don't realize the specifics behind it. So I find it as the last major genre that is worth mentioning.


Overall - 98 out of 100

Shuffle! hit me hard with all of it's dramatic, romantic, and anxious scenes. I find this as one of my favorite anime and I can't see why anyone would find it any worse, but I guess personal opinions matter the most. If you are reading this and haven't watched Shuffle! yet, I highly reccomend you do, because it stirs emotions in you that you may never had experienced.


I have written A LOT because I felt the need to show the people that dislike it are so very general with their dislikes. Hopefully reading my specifics helped clear some things up. And if you noticed that I didn't include comedy or fantasy as one of the rating scales, that doesn't mean they aren't important. The comedy helped get through some scenes, and Asa was completely full of laughter, as was the princess's fathers. And fantasy is hugely important due to the fact that Sia is from the World of the Gods, and Nerine being from the World of Demons. 


Thanks for reading this review. If you have any questions about my genre rating scale, then just message me. I leave you with the traditional ratings.


Story - 10/10

Art - 10+/10

Sound - 10/10

Character - 10/10

Enjoyment - 10+/10

Overall - 10/10
